1824    /**
1825     * Given a char and a Color, makes a ColorChangeImage of that colored char so it can be rotated and so on.
1826     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1827     * @param color a Color to use for the image; will not change even though ColorChangeImage permits this
1828     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1829     */
1830    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Color color)
1831    {
1832        return makeGlyphImage(glyph, color, false);
1833    }
1834    /**
1835     * Given a char and a Color, makes a ColorChangeImage of that colored char so it can be rotated and so on.
1836     * This overload allows double-width mode to be specified.
1837     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1838     * @param color a Color to use for the image; will not change even though ColorChangeImage permits this
1839     * @param doubleWidth true if layout uses two chars of width per logical cell, false otherwise
1840     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1841     */
1842    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Color color, boolean doubleWidth)
1843    {
1844        if (!initialized) {
1845            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1846        }
1847        TextureRegion tr;
1848        if (glyphTextures.containsKey(glyph))
1849        {
1850            tr = glyphTextures.get(glyph);
1851        }
1852        else
1853        {
1854            BitmapFont.Glyph g = bmpFont.getData().getGlyph(glyph);
1855            tr = new TextureRegion(bmpFont.getRegion(g.page), g.srcX, g.srcY, g.width, g.height);
1856            glyphTextures.put(glyph, tr);
1857        }
1858
1859        ColorChangeImage im = new ColorChangeImage(tr, 1, doubleWidth,
1860                actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0), Maker.makeList(scc.filter(color)));
1861        im.setAlign(2);
1862        im.setSize(actualCellWidth * (doubleWidth ? 2 : 1), actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1863        return im;
1864    }
1865    /**
1866     * Given a char and a Collection of Color (such as a List that might be produced by
1867     * {@link SquidColorCenter#gradient(Color, Color)}), makes a ColorChangeImage of that char so it can be rotated and
1868     * so on. The colors will cycle through the given collection onceper {@code loopTime} seconds. You can specify
1869     * double-width mode if you use it, probably in SquidPanel or SquidLayers.
1870     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1871     * @param colors a Collection of Colors to use for the image; the image will cycle through them in order
1872     * @param loopTime the amount of time, in seconds, it should take for all colors to be cycled through
1873     * @param doubleWidth true if layout uses two chars of width per logical cell, false otherwise
1874     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1875     */
1876    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Collection<Color> colors, float loopTime, boolean doubleWidth) {
1877        if (!initialized) {
1878            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1879        }
1880        TextureRegion tr;
1881        if (glyphTextures.containsKey(glyph))
1882        {
1883            tr = glyphTextures.get(glyph);
1884        }
1885        else
1886        {
1887            BitmapFont.Glyph g = bmpFont.getData().getGlyph(glyph);
1888            tr = new TextureRegion(bmpFont.getRegion(g.page), g.srcX, g.srcY, g.width, g.height);
1889            glyphTextures.put(glyph, tr);
1890        }
1891        ArrayList<Color> colors2 = null;
1892        if (colors != null && !colors.isEmpty()) {
1893            colors2 = new ArrayList<>(colors.size());
1894            for (Color c : colors) {
1895                colors2.add(scc.filter(c));
1896            }
1897        }
1898        ColorChangeImage im = new ColorChangeImage(tr, loopTime, doubleWidth,
1899                actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0), colors2);
1900        im.setAlign(2);
1901        im.setSize(actualCellWidth * (doubleWidth ? 2 : 1), actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1902        return im;
1903    }

1912    public Actor makeActor(TextureRegion tr, Color color) {

1914            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1915        }

1917            Image im = new Image(block);
1918            im.setColor(scc.filter(color));
1919            im.setSize(width, height);
1920            // im.setPosition(x - width * 0.5f, y - height * 0.5f, Align.center);
1921            return im;
1922        } else {
1923            Image im = new Image(tr);
1924            im.setColor(scc.filter(color));
1925            im.setSize(width, height);
1926            // im.setPosition(x - width * 0.5f, y - height * 0.5f, Align.center);
1927            return im;
1928        }

1938    public Actor makeActor(TextureRegion tr, Color color, float width, float height) {

1940            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");

1945            im.setSize(width, height);
1946            // im.setPosition(x - width * 0.5f, y - height * 0.5f, Align.center);

1967    /**
1968     * Gets a Glyph with the given char to show, libGDX Color, and position as x and y in world coordinates.
1969     * Glyph is a kind of scene2d Actor that uses this TextCellFactory to handle its rendering instead of delegating
1970     * that to the Label class from scene2d.ui.

1972     * @param color the color as a libGDX Color; can also be an SColor or some other subclass of Color
1973     * @param x the x position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()
1974     * @param y the y position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()
1975     * @return a new Glyph that will use the specified char, color, and position
1976     */
1977
1978    public Glyph glyph(char shown, Color color, float x, float y)
1979    {
1980        return new Glyph(shown, color, x, y);

1984     * Gets a Glyph with the given char to show, color as a packed float, and position as x and y in world coordinates.
1985     * Glyph is a kind of scene2d Actor that uses this TextCellFactory to handle its rendering instead of delegating
1986     * that to the Label class from scene2d.ui.
1987     * @param shown char to show; if this is the char with codepoint 0, then this will show a solid block
1988     * @param encodedColor the encoded color as a float, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
1989     * @param x the x position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()
1990     * @param y the y position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()
1991     * @return a new Glyph that will use the specified char, color, and position
1992     */
1993    public Glyph glyph(char shown, float encodedColor, float x, float y)

1999        return msdf;

2003        return distanceField;

2007        return distanceFieldScaleX;
2008    }

2010        return distanceFieldScaleY;

2012
2013    /**
2014     * If this uses a distance field font, the smoothing multiplier affects how crisp or blurry lines are, with higher
2015     * numbers generally resulting in more crisp fonts, but numbers that are too high cause jagged aliasing. This starts
2016     * at 1.2f, usually ({@link DefaultResources} notes when a different value is used).
2017     * @return the current smoothing multiplier as a float, which starts at 1.2f for most fonts
2018     */
2019    public float getSmoothingMultiplier() {
2020        return smoothingMultiplier;
2021    }
2022
2023    /**
2024     * If this uses a distance field font, the smoothing multiplier affects how crisp or blurry lines are, with higher
2025     * numbers generally resulting in more crisp fonts, but numbers that are too high cause jagged aliasing. Before this
2026     * is called, the smoothing multiplier is usually 1.2f; {@link DefaultResources} notes when other values are used.
2027     * @param smoothingMultiplier the new value for the smoothing multiplier as a float; should be fairly close to 1f.
2028     * @return this for chaining
2029     */
2030    public TextCellFactory setSmoothingMultiplier(float smoothingMultiplier) {
2031        this.smoothingMultiplier = smoothingMultiplier;
2032        return this;
2033    }
2034
2035    /**
2036     * If using a distance field font, you MUST call this at some point while the batch has begun, or use code that
2037     * calls it for you (which is now much of SquidLib). A typical point to call it is in the
2038     * "void draw(Batch batch, float parentAlpha)" method or an overriding method for a Scene2D class. You should call
2039     * configureShader rarely, typically only a few times per frame if there are no images to render, and this means the
2040     * logical place to call it is in the outermost Group that contains any SquidPanel objects or other widgets. If you
2041     * have multipleTextCellFactory objects, each one needs to have configureShader called before it is used to draw.
2042     * <br>
2043     * SquidLayers, SparseLayers, SubcellLayers, SquidPanel, TextPanel, and ImageSquidPanel already call
2044     * this method in their draw overrides, so you don't need to call this manually if you use any of those. None of
2045     * those classes change the shader after they set it for their uses, so you may need to set the shader on your Batch
2046     * to null to revert to the default shader if you need to draw full-color art.
2047     * <br>
2048     * If you don't use a distance field font, you don't need to call this, but calling it won't cause problems.
2049     *
2050     * @param batch the Batch, such as a {@link FilterBatch}, to configure to render distance field fonts if necessary.
2051     */
2052    public void configureShader(Batch batch) {
2053        if(initialized)
2054        {
2055            if(msdf)
2056            {
2057                if(!shader.equals(batch.getShader())) 
2058                    batch.setShader(shader);
2059                shader.setUniformf("u_smoothing", 2.1198158f * smoothingMultiplier * bmpFont.getData().scaleX);
2060            }
2061            else if (distanceField) {
2062                if(!shader.equals(batch.getShader()))
2063                    batch.setShader(shader);
2064                shader.setUniformf("u_smoothing", 0.25f / (smoothingMultiplier * (bmpFont.getData().scaleX)));
2065            }
2066        }
2067    }
2068    /**
2069     * Releases all resources of this object.
2070     */
2071    @Override
2072    public void dispose() {
2073        if(block != null) block.getTexture().dispose();
2074        if(bmpFont != null) bmpFont.dispose();
2075    }
2076
2077    /**
2078     * Gets the descent of this TextCellFactory's BitmapFont, which may be useful for layout outside this class.
2079     * @return the descent of the BitmapFont this object uses
2080     */
2081    public float getDescent() {
2082        return descent;
2083    }
2084
2085    public char getDirectionGlyph() {
2086        return directionGlyph;
2087    }
2088
2089    public TextCellFactory setDirectionGlyph(char directionGlyph) {
2090        this.directionGlyph = directionGlyph;
2091        return this;
2092    }
2093
2094    /**
2095     * Adds a pair of Strings (typically both with length 1) as a replacement pair, so when the find String is requested
2096     * to be drawn, the replace String is used instead. Swaps are used when drawing text in each cell in SquidPanel and
2097     * related classes, so Strings longer than 1 char are effectively disregarded beyond the first char.
2098     * <br>
2099     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2100     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2101     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap("^", ",")} and also
2102     * {@code addSwap(",", ":")}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2103     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2104     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2105     * @param find the requested String that will be changed
2106     * @param replace the replacement String that will be used in place of find
2107     * @return this for chaining
2108     */
2109    public TextCellFactory addSwap(String find, String replace)
2110    {
2111        if(find == null || replace == null || find.isEmpty()  || replace.isEmpty() || find.charAt(0) == 0)
2112            return this;
2113        swap.put(find.charAt(0), replace.charAt(0));
2114        return this;
2115    }
2116
2117    /**
2118     * Adds a pair of chars as a replacement pair, so when the find char is requested to be drawn, the replace char is
2119     * used instead.
2120     * <br>
2121     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2122     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2123     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2124     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2125     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2126     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2127     * @param find the requested char that will be changed (converted to a length-1 String)
2128     * @param replace the replacement char that will be used in place of find (converted to a length-1 String)
2129     * @return this for chaining
2130     */
2131    public TextCellFactory addSwap(char find, char replace)
2132    {
2133        if(find == 0)
2134            return this;
2135        swap.put(find, replace);
2136        return this;
2137    }
2138
2139    /**
2140     * Removes the replacement pair, if present, that searches for the given key, find. Swaps are used when drawing text
2141     * in each cell in SquidPanel and related classes, so Strings longer than 1 char are effectively disregarded beyond
2142     * the first char.
2143     * <br>
2144     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2145     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2146     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2147     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2148     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2149     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2150     * @param find the String that would be changed in the replacement pair
2151     * @return this for chaining
2152     */
2153    public TextCellFactory removeSwap(String find)
2154    {
2155
2156        if(find != null && !find.isEmpty() && find.charAt(0) != 0)
2157            swap.remove(find.charAt(0));
2158        return this;
2159    }
2160
2161    /**
2162     * Removes the replacement pair, if present, that searches for the given key, find.
2163     * <br>
2164     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2165     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2166     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2167     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2168     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2169     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2170     * @return this for chaining
2171     */
2172    public TextCellFactory removeSwap(char find)
2173    {
2174        swap.remove(find);
2175        return this;
2176    }
2177
2178    /**
2179     * Gets the current mapping of "swaps", or replacement pairs, to replace keys requested for drawing with their
2180     * values in the {@link CharCharMap}. CharCharMap is a class from RegExodus (a dependency of squidlib-util that is
2181     * used for text matching and Unicode support), which is used here to avoid making yet another primitive-backed
2182     * collection class.
2183     * <br>
2184     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2185     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2186     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2187     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2188     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2189     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2190     * @return the mapping of replacement pairs
2191     */
2192    public CharCharMap getAllSwaps() {
2193        return swap;
2194    }
2195
2196    /**
2197     * Sets the mapping of replacement pairs to a different one as a Map of Character keys to String values.
2198     * <br>
2199     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2200     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2201     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2202     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2203     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2204     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2205     * @param swaps the Map of replacement pairs; keys requested for drawing will be replaced with their values
2206     * @return this for chaining
2207     */
2208    public TextCellFactory setAllSwaps(OrderedMap<Character, Character> swaps) {
2209        swap.clear();
2210        for (int i = 0; i < swaps.size(); i++) {
2211            if(!swaps.keyAt(i).equals('\0'))
2212                swap.put(swaps.keyAt(i), swaps.getAt(i));
2213        }
2214        return this;
2215    }
2216
2217    /**
2218     * Appends to the mapping of replacement pairs, adding or replacing any entries in the current mapping with the
2219     * entries in a Map of Character keys to String values.
2220     * <br>
2221     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2222     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2223     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2224     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2225     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2226     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2227     * @param swaps the Map of replacement pairs to add; keys requested for drawing will be replaced with their values
2228     * @return this for chaining
2229     */
2230    public TextCellFactory addSwaps(OrderedMap<Character, Character> swaps) {
2231        for (int i = 0; i < swaps.size(); i++) {
2232            if(!swaps.keyAt(i).equals('\0'))
2233                swap.put(swaps.keyAt(i), swaps.getAt(i));
2234        }
2235        return this;
2236    }
2237
2238    /**
2239     * Clears all replacement pairs this has been told to swap.
2240     * <br>
2241     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2242     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2243     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2244     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2245     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2246     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2247     * @return this for chaining
2248     */
2249    public TextCellFactory clearSwaps()
2250    {
2251        swap.clear();
2252        return this;
2253    }

2255    /**
2256     * Not implemented in this class; in subclasses that do, this should change the currently-used font style, such as
2257     * from regular to italic or bold. Calling this method on a TextCellFactory does nothing, but won't cause problems.
2258     * @param style an int, typically a constant in a class that implements this, that determines what style to use.
2259     */
2260    public void setStyle(int style)
2261    {
2262    }
2263
2264    /**
2265     * A kind of Actor for one char (with one color) that is innately drawn with a specific TextCellFactory, and will
2266     * match the layout behavior of that TextCellFactory when it is used for other purposes. This is an inner class of
2267     * TextCellFactory, and can't be constructed without a TextCellFactory being involved; usually you instantiate
2268     * Glyphs with {@link #glyph(char, Color, float, float)} or an overload of that method on TextCellFactory.
2269     */
2270    public class Glyph extends Actor implements ICellVisible
2271    {
2272        /**
2273         * The char that will be shown for this Glyph.
2274         */
2275        public char shown;
2276        
2277        @Override
2278        public char getSymbol()
2279        {
2280            return shown;
2281        }
2282
2283        /**
2284         * Makes an orange '@' Glyph at 0,0 in world coordinates.
2285         */
2286        public Glyph() {
2287            this('@', SColor.SAFETY_ORANGE, 0f, 0f);
2288        }
2289
2290        /**
2291         * Makes a Glyph of the given char in the given Color, at the specified world coordinates.
2292         * @param shown the char to show
2293         * @param color the Color to use; if null this will instead use {@link SColor#TRANSPARENT}
2294         * @param x x position in world coordinates
2295         * @param y y position in world coordinates
2296         */
2297        public Glyph(char shown, Color color, float x, float y)
2298        {
2299            super();
2300            this.shown = shown;
2301            super.getColor().set(color == null ? SColor.TRANSPARENT : color);
2302            setPosition(x, y);
2303        }
2304
2305        /**
2306         * Makes a Glyph of the given char in the given packed float color, at the specified world coordinates.
2307         * @param shown the char to show
2308         * @param color the packed float color to use, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
2309         * @param x x position in world coordinates
2310         * @param y y position in world coordinates
2311         */
2312        public Glyph(char shown, float color, float x, float y) {
2313            super();
2314            this.shown = shown;
2315            Color.abgr8888ToColor(super.getColor(), color);
2316            setPosition(x, y);
2317        }
2318
2319        /**
2320         * Gets the color of this Glyph as a packed float color; does not allocate any objects.
2321         * @return the color of this Glyph as a packed float
2322         */
2323        @Override
2324        public float getPackedColor() {
2325            return getColor().toFloatBits();
2326        }
2327
2328        /**
2329         * Sets the color of this Glyph with the given packed float color; does not allocate any objects.
2330         * @param color the color to set this Glyph to, as a packed float
2331         */
2332        public void setPackedColor(float color) {
2333            Color.abgr8888ToColor(super.getColor(), color);
2334        }
2335
2336        @Override
2337        public String toString() {
2338            return "Glyph{'" +
2339                    + shown +
2340                    "' with color " + getColor() +
2341                    ", position (" + getX() +
2342                    "," + getY() +
2343                    ")}";
2344        }
2345
2346        /**
2347         * Draws the actor. The batch is configured to draw in the parent's coordinate system.
2348         * {@link Batch#begin()} must have already been called on the batch before this method.
2349         *
2350         * @param batch the batch should be between begin() and end(), usually handled by Stage
2351         * @param parentAlpha Multiplied with this Glyph's alpha, allowing a parent's alpha to affect all children.
2352         */
2353        @Override
2354        public void draw(Batch batch, float parentAlpha) {
2355            TextCellFactory.this.draw(batch, shown, SColor.multiplyAlpha(getColor(), parentAlpha), getX(), getY() + 1);
2356        }
2357    }
2358}
